  <p style="line-height:10.3pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Fee paid previously with preliminary
  materials.</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="4%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.34%;">
  <p style="line-height:10.3pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Wingdings" style="font-size:9.5pt;">o</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="95%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:95.66%;">
  <p style="line-height:10.3pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Check box if any part of the fee is offset
  as provided by Exchange Act Rule&nbsp;0-11(a)(2)&nbsp;and identify the filing
  for which the offsetting fee was paid previously. Identify the previous
  filing by registration statement number, or the Form&nbsp;or Schedule and the
  date of its filing.</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>

  <td width="4%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.34%;">

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="6" face="Times New Roman" style="font-weight:bold;"><img width="276" height="149" src="g78561bci001.gif" alt="GRAPHIC"></font></b></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 24.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">THE AES CORPORATION<br>
4300 WILSON BOULEVARD<br>
<font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">ARLINGTON, VA 22203</font></font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">April&nbsp;4,
2006</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><a name="DearFellowStockholders_160532"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Dear Fellow
Stockholders:</font></p>

<p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">On behalf of
the Board of Directors, may I please invite you to attend the 2006 Annual
Meeting of Stockholders of The AES Corporation (&#147;AES&#148;). The Annual Meeting will
be held on Thursday, May&nbsp;11, 2006, at 9:30&nbsp;a.m. in the Rotunda
Conference Room&nbsp;on the 9</font><font size="1" style="font-size:6.0pt;position:relative;top:-2.0pt;">th</font>&#160;floor of the AES corporate headquarters
located at 4300 Wilson Boulevard, Arlington, Virginia.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The attached
Proxy Statement provides information regarding the matters to be voted on at
the Annual Meeting. The 2005 Annual Report to Stockholders is also enclosed.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Should you
choose to attend the Annual Meeting in person, you would have the opportunity
to address questions regarding the Company directly to the Board, senior
management, and the Company&#146;s independent auditors.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Whether you are able to attend the Annual
Meeting or not, we would strongly encourage you to vote your shares. You can
vote by marking, signing and returning the enclosed Proxy. Alternatively,
Stockholders may vote by telephone or via the Internet. To ensure that your
shares will be represented and voted at the Annual Meeting, I respectfully urge
that you vote your Proxy as soon as possible&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;and thank you for your
continued interest in AES.</font></p>

<div align="center">

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
 <div style="border:none;border-top:double windowtext 6.0pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;"> <p style="border:none;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;padding:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The AES Corporation<br>
4300 Wilson Boulevard<br>
Arlington, Virginia 22203</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><a name="NoticeOf2006AnnualMeetingOfStockh_035832"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">NOTICE OF 2006
ANNUAL MEETING OF STOCKHOLDERS OF THE AES CORPORATION<br>
TO BE HELD ON THURSDAY, MAY&nbsp;11, 2006</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">April&nbsp;4,
2006</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">TO THE HOLDERS
OF COMMON STOCK OF THE AES CORPORATION:</font></p>

<p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The 2006 Annual
Meeting of Stockholders of The AES Corporation will be held on Thursday, May 11,
2006, at 9:30 a.m. in the Rotunda Conference Room on the 9</font><font size="1" style="font-size:6.0pt;position:relative;top:-2.0pt;">th</font>&#160;floor of the Company&#146;s corporate offices
located at 4300 Wilson Boulevard, Arlington, Virginia. Doors to the Annual
Meeting will open at 8:30 a.m.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Annual Meeting will be conducted to address the following matters:</font></p>

<p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">1.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>To elect 10
members to the Board of Directors;</p>

<p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">2.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>To consider and
vote on a proposal to ratify the appointment of Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP
as the independent auditors of the Company for the year 2006;</p>

<p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">3.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>To consider and
vote on a proposal to adopt The AES Corporation Performance Incentive Plan (the
&#147;Incentive Plan&#148;) (approved by the Board of Directors as described in the
following Proxy Statement); and</p>

<p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">4.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>To
transact such other business as may properly come before the Annual Meeting.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Stockholders of record at the close of
business on March&nbsp;3, 2006 are entitled to notice of and to vote at the
Annual Meeting.</font></p>

<div align="center">

  </td>
  <td width="315" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:236.55pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">and Secretary</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">EACH STOCKHOLDER IS REQUESTED TO EXECUTE AND PROMPTLY RETURN THE ENCLOSED
PROXY CARD. A PREPAID ENVELOPE IS ENCLOSED FOR RETURNING PROXY CARDS.
ALTERNATIVELY, STOCKHOLDERS MAY&nbsp;VOTE BY TELEPHONE OR VIA THE INTERNET (SEE
DIRECTIONS ON THE ENCLOSED PROXY CARD). ANY STOCKHOLDER SUBMITTING A PROXY CARD
HAS THE POWER TO REVOKE THE VOTE SET FORTH IN SUCH PROXY CARD AT ANY TIME PRIOR
TO THE SUBMISSION OF VOTES AT THE ANNUAL MEETING. STOCKHOLDERS WHO ARE PRESENT
AT THE ANNUAL MEETING MAY&nbsp;WITHDRAW THEIR PROXY AND VOTE IN PERSON.</font></b></p>


 <div style="border:none;border-top:double windowtext 6.0pt;padding:12.0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;"> <p align="center" style="border:none;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;padding:0pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">2</font></p> </div>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

  <td width="577" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:433.1pt;">
  <p align="left" style="line-height:9.5pt;margin:1.0pt 0pt .0001pt 15.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;text-indent:-7.5pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.5pt;"><a href="a06-7856_1def14a.htm#AesCodeOfBusinessConductAndEthics_055730" title="Click to goto ">AES Code of Business Conduct and Ethics and Corporate
  Governance Guidelines</a></font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

  </td>

  </td>

  Compliance</a></font></p>

 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:15.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">3</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='3',FILE='C:\fc\94162645918_D11854_997692\7856-1-bg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 16:27 2006' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

<div>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;width:100.0%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="100%" style="background:#EBEBEB;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:3.0pt 0pt;text-align:center;"><a name="ProxyStatement_133321"></a><font size="3" style="font-size:12.0pt;">PROXY STATEMENT</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 20.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">April&nbsp;4,
2006</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The
accompanying Proxy is solicited by the Board of Directors (the &#147;Board&#148;) of The
AES Corporation (the &#147;Company&#148; or &#147;AES&#148;). The Proxy is solicited for use at the
2006 Annual Meeting of Stockholders of the Company.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Annual
Meeting will commence at 9:30&nbsp;a.m. on Thursday, May&nbsp;11, 2006. The
Annual Meeting will be held in the 9</font><font size="1" style="font-size:6.0pt;position:relative;top:-2.0pt;">th</font>&#160;floor Rotunda Conference Room&nbsp;of the
Company&#146;s corporate offices located at 4300 Wilson Boulevard, Arlington,
Virginia. Any adjournment of the Annual Meeting will be held at the same
address. Directions to the Annual Meeting are located on page&nbsp;39 of this
Proxy Statement.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">This Proxy
Statement provides information regarding the matters to be voted on at the
Annual Meeting as well as other information that may be useful to you. The
Company&#146;s Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31,
2005 also is enclosed with this Proxy Statement.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">This Proxy
Statement and accompanying Proxy Card are first being sent to Stockholders on
or about April&nbsp;17, 2006.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="QuestionsAndAnswersRegardingThePr_160530"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Questions and Answers Regarding the Proxy Statement
and Annual Meeting</font></b></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="QuestionsAndAnswersRegardingThePr_182331"></a><a name="WhatIsTheRecordDate_041800"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">WHAT IS THE RECORD DATE?</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The record date
is established by the Board as required by Delaware law. Owners of record of
the Company&#146;s Common Stock at the close of business on the record date are
entitled to receive notice of the Annual Meeting. Such owners of record are
also entitled to vote at the Annual Meeting and any adjournments of the Annual
Meeting. Each share of Common Stock is entitled to one vote. The record date
established for this year has been determined to be March&nbsp;3, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="HowDoesAStockholderSubmitAVoteOnA_041801"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">HOW DOES A STOCKHOLDER SUBMIT A VOTE ON A
PROPOSAL?</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">A Stockholder
may vote by marking, signing, dating and returning the enclosed Proxy Card in
the enclosed prepaid envelope. Alternatively, a Stockholder may vote by
telephone, via the Internet, or in person by attending the Annual Meeting. Only
Stockholders registered on the books of the Company&#146;s transfer agent may vote
in person at the Annual Meeting. Instructions on how to vote by phone or via
the Internet are set forth on the enclosed Proxy Card. If a Stockholder owns
shares through a broker or other intermediary, voting instructions are set
forth on the enclosed voting instruction card.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">If a Proxy is
properly executed, the shares it represents will be voted at the Annual Meeting
in accordance with the instructions noted on the Proxy. If no instructions are
specified in the Proxy with respect to the matters to be acted upon, the shares
represented by the Proxy will be voted in accordance with the recommendations
of the Board. The recommendations of the Board regarding the matters to be
acted upon at the Annual Meeting are set forth in this Proxy Statement. Proxies
marked as abstentions, or to withhold a vote from a Nominee as in the case of
Proposal I for election of Directors, will have the effect of a negative vote.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">4</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='4',FILE='C:\fc\94145337247_D11854_997353\7856-1-ca.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 14:54 2006' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="MayaStockholderChangeAVote_041807"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">MAY&nbsp;A STOCKHOLDER CHANGE A VOTE?</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Stockholders
are entitled to revoke their proxies at any time before their shares are voted
at the Annual Meeting. To revoke a Proxy, a Stockholder must file&nbsp;a
written notice of revocation with the Company, or deliver a duly executed Proxy
bearing a later date than the original submitted Proxy, or attend the Annual
Meeting and vote in person.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="HowManySharesOfStockWereOutstandi_041808"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">HOW MANY SHARES OF STOCK WERE OUTSTANDING ON
THE RECORD DATE?</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">At the close of
business on March&nbsp;3, 2006, there were 657,601,448 shares of AES Common
Stock outstanding.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="WhatIsABrokerNonvote_041809"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">WHAT IS A BROKER NON-VOTE?</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">A beneficial
owner is a stockholder who has engaged a nominee, such as a broker, to hold
shares for or on behalf of the beneficial owner. A broker non-vote occurs when
a nominee submits a Proxy but has not received voting instructions from the
beneficial owner with respect to a particular matter and the nominee does not
possess or choose to exercise his/her discretionary authority to vote the
shares for the particular matter. A broker non-vote will be considered as
present at the Annual Meeting for purposes of establishing a quorum. A broker
non-vote will not be counted as a vote for or against a Proposal.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="WhatConstitutesAQuorum_041810"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">WHAT CONSTITUTES A QUORUM?</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Under the
Company By-Laws, a quorum is a majority of the outstanding shares of AES Common
Stock entitled to vote. The number of outstanding shares of Common Stock
entitled to vote at the Annual Meeting is determined as of the record date.
Abstentions and broker non-votes are counted in determining whether a quorum is
present for the Annual Meeting. A copy of the By-laws is available on the
Company website (<u>www.aes.com</u>).</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="AreVotingRecordsConfidential_041811"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">ARE VOTING RECORDS CONFIDENTIAL?</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Company
requires that vote tabulators and the inspector of the election execute
agreements to maintain the confidentiality of voting records. Voting records
will remain confidential except as necessary to meet legal requirements and in
other limited circumstances such as Proxy contests.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="HowDoesTheCompanySolicitProxies_041812"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">HOW DOES THE COMPANY SOLICIT PROXIES?</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Proxies will be
solicited by mail, telephone, or other means of communication. The cost of the
solicitation of proxies will be borne by the Company. The Company has retained
Computershare Trust Co., N.A. (&#147;Computershare&#148;) and Corporate Investor
Communications,&nbsp;Inc., to assist in the solicitation of proxies from
Stockholders and the Company will pay a fee estimated at $8,000, plus expenses,
for such services. In addition, solicitation may be made by Directors,
officers, and other employees of the Company. The Company reimburses brokerage
firms, custodians, nominees, and fiduciaries in accordance with the rules&nbsp;of
the National Association of Securities Dealers,&nbsp;Inc., for reasonable
expenses incurred by them in forwarding materials to the beneficial owners of
shares of the Company&#146;s Common Stock.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">5</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='5',FILE='C:\fc\94145337247_D11854_997353\7856-1-ca.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 14:54 2006' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><a name="Proposal1ElectionOfDirectors_133356"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;width:100.0%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="100%" valign="top" style="background:#EBEBEB;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:3.0pt 0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><font size="3" style="font-size:12.0pt;">PROPOSAL 1: ELECTION OF DIRECTORS</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Board
submits the names of the 10 persons (&#147;Nominees&#148;) identified and discussed in
the paragraphs below for election to the Board of Directors of the Company. Roger
W. Sant has decided not to stand for reelection this year and is therefore not
included among the nominees below.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">In 2005, the
Board met ten (10)&nbsp;times, including five (5)&nbsp;telephonic meetings. In
accordance with the Company&#146;s Corporate Governance Guidelines, non-management
Directors meet after each in-person meeting of the Board. Non-management
Directors met five (5)&nbsp;times in 2005 with Mr.&nbsp;Darman presiding as
Lead Independent Director. All Directors attended at least 80% of all meetings
of the Board and Committees on which they serve. Board members are expected to
attend all meetings of the Board, including the Annual Meeting and meetings of
the Board committees on which they serve.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Only one of the
Nominees, Paul Hanrahan, is also an employee of the Company. The Board has
determined that each of the Nominees standing for election, except Paul
Hanrahan, the President and Chief Executive Officer of the Company, meet the
standards of independence established by the New York Stock Exchange (&#147;NYSE&#148;)
and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">A Nominee will
be elected to serve as a Director if a majority of the votes of the shares of
Common Stock present in person or represented by Proxy at the Annual Meeting,
at which a quorum is present, are voted in favor of the Nominee. Directors are
elected to hold office until the next Annual Meeting of Stockholders and until
their respective successors have been elected and qualified.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><a name="RichardDarmanHasBeenADirectorOfAe_161804"></a><font style="font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Richard Darman</font></i></b></font>
has been a Director of AES since July&nbsp;2002. He served as Vice Chairman
from December 2002 until May 2003, and was elected Chairman of the Board on May
1, 2003. In addition to his service as Chairman, Mr.&nbsp;Darman serves as Lead
Independent Director of the Board. He is a Partner and Managing Director of The
Carlyle Group (&#147;Carlyle&#148;), one of the world&#146;s largest private equity firms. He
joined Carlyle in February&nbsp;1993, after serving in the cabinet of the first
Bush administration as Director of the U.S. Office of Management and Budget
(from 1989 to 1993). Prior to joining the Bush cabinet, he was a Managing
Director of Shearson Lehman Brothers, Deputy Secretary of the U.S. Treasury,
and Assistant to the President of the United States. He graduated with honors
from Harvard College in 1964 and from the Harvard Graduate School of Business
Administration in 1967. He is a Trustee of the publicly traded IXIS Funds and
Loomis-Sayles Funds, trustee of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, and
is Chairman of the Board of the Smithsonian National Museum of American
History. Mr.&nbsp;Darman chairs the Special Committee of the Board (and will
Chair the newly formed Finance and Investment Committee) and serves as an
ex-officio member of each committee of the Board. The Board has determined that
Mr.&nbsp;Darman meets the standards of &#147;independence&#148; established by the NYSE
and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><a name="PaulHanrahanHasBeenADirectorOfAes_161809"></a><font style="font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Paul Hanrahan</font></i></b></font>
has been a Director of AES since June 2002. At that time he was also appointed
President and Chief Executive Officer. Prior to assuming his current position, Mr.&nbsp;Hanrahan
was the Chief Operating Officer and Executive Vice President of AES where he
was responsible for business development activities and the operation of
multiple electric utilities and generation facilities in Europe, Asia and Latin
America. In addition, Mr.&nbsp;Hanrahan was previously the President and CEO of
AES China Generating Co.&nbsp;Ltd., a public company formerly listed on NASDAQ.
He also managed other AES businesses in the U.S, Europe and Asia. Prior to
joining AES, Mr.&nbsp;Hanrahan served as a line officer on a fast attack
nuclear submarine, USS Parche (SSN-683). </p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">6</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='6',FILE='C:\fc\94145337247_D11854_997353\7856-1-ca.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 14:54 2006' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">In March&nbsp;2006, he was elected to the board of Corn Products
International,&nbsp;Inc. He is a graduate of Harvard School of Business and the
U.S. Naval Academy.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><a name="KristinaM_JohnsonHasBeenADirector_161813"></a><font style="font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Kristina M.
Johnson</font></i></b></font> has been a Director of AES since April&nbsp;2004.
Dr.&nbsp;Johnson is the chief academic and administrative officer (Dean) of the
Edmund T. Pratt,&nbsp;Jr., School of Engineering at Duke University (&#147;Duke&#148;).
She joined Duke in July&nbsp;1999. Prior to joining Duke, Dr.&nbsp;Johnson
served on the faculty at the University of Colorado at Boulder, from 1985-1999
as a Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering, and as a co-founder
and Director (1993-1997) of the National Science Foundation Engineering
Research Center for Optoelectronic Computing Systems Center. Dr.&nbsp;Johnson
received her BS with distinction, MS and PhD from Stanford University in
Electrical Engineering. She is an expert in liquid crystal electro-optics
and has over forty patents or patents pending in this field. Dr.&nbsp;Johnson
currently serves on the Boards of Directors of Minerals Technologies,&nbsp;Inc.,
and Guidant Corporation. Dr.&nbsp;Johnson serves on the Compensation Committee
and the Environment, Safety and Technology Committee of the Board. The Board
has determined that Dr.&nbsp;Johnson meets the standards of &#147;independence&#148;
established by the NYSE and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><a name="JohnA_KoskinenHasBeenADirectorOfA_161818"></a><font style="font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">John A.
Koskinen</font></i></b></font> has been a Director of AES since April&nbsp;2004.
Mr.&nbsp;Koskinen is President of the United States Soccer Foundation, a
position he has held since June&nbsp;2004. Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Koskinen served
as Deputy Mayor and City Administrator for the District of Columbia from 2000
to 2003. From 2001 to 2004 Mr.&nbsp;Koskinen served as a Director of the US
Soccer Foundation and served on the Foundation&#146;s audit committee. Prior to his
election as Deputy Mayor, he occupied several positions with the U.S.
Government, including service from 1994 through 1997 as Deputy Director for
Management, Office of Management and Budget. From 1998 to 2000, he served as
Assistant to the President (President Clinton) and Chaired the President&#146;s
Council on Year 2000 Conversion. Prior to his most recent service with the U.S.
Government, in 1973, Mr.&nbsp;Koskinen joined the Palmieri Company, which
specialized in turnaround management, as Vice President and later served as
President and CEO from 1979 through 1993. Mr.&nbsp;Koskinen graduated with a
JD, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">cum laude</font></i>, from Yale
University School of Law and a BA, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">magna cum
laude</font></i>, in physics from Duke University where he was a member of Phi
Beta Kappa. Mr.&nbsp;Koskinen serves on the Financial Audit Committee and the
Environment, Safety and Technology Committee of the Board. Mr.&nbsp;Koskinen
has been designated an Audit Committee Financial Expert pursuant to Section&nbsp;407
of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. The Board has determined that Mr.&nbsp;Koskinen
meets the standards of &#147;independence&#148; established by the NYSE and the Sarbanes-Oxley
Act.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><a name="PhilipLaderHasBeenADirectorOfAesS_161822"></a><font style="font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Philip Lader</font></i></b></font>
has been a Director of AES since April&nbsp;2001. The former U.S. Ambassador to
the Court of St. James&#146;s, he is Chairman of WPP Group plc, the global
advertising and communications services company which includes J. Walter
Thompson, Young&nbsp;&amp; Rubicam, and Ogilvy&nbsp;&amp; Mather. A lawyer, he
is also a Senior Advisor to Morgan Stanley, a Director of Lloyd&#146;s of London,
WPP Group plc, RAND and Marathon Oil Corporations, and a trustee of the British
Museum. Formerly White House Deputy Chief of Staff, Assistant to the President,
Deputy Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Administrator of
the U.S. Small Business Administration, he also was President of Sea Pines
Company, Executive Vice President of the U.S. holdings of the late Sir James
Goldsmith, and president of universities in South Carolina and Australia. He
was educated at Duke University (BA, Phi Beta Kappa, 1966), the University of
Michigan (MA, 1967), Oxford University, and Harvard Law School (JD, 1972). Mr.&nbsp;Lader
chairs the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee and also serves on the
Environment, Safety and Technology Committee of the Board. The Board has
determined that Mr.&nbsp;Lader meets the standards of &#147;independence&#148;
established by the NYSE and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><a name="JohnH_McarthurHasBeenADirectorOfA_161844"></a><font style="font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">John H.
McArthur</font></i></b></font> has been a Director of AES since January&nbsp;1997.
He is the retired Dean of the Harvard Business School, and has been a private
business consultant and active investor in various companies since prior </p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">7</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">to 1994. He is a member of the Boards of Directors of BCE&nbsp;Inc.,
Bell Canada, Bell Canada Enterprises, Cabot Corporation, HCA Corporation, KOC
Holdings, A.S. Istanbul, Reuters Founders Share Company, London, and Telesat
Canada. Mr.&nbsp;McArthur chairs the Financial Audit Committee and serves on
the Special Committee of the Board (and will serve on the newly formed Finance
and Investment Committee). Mr.&nbsp;McArthur has been designated an Audit
Committee Financial Expert pursuant to Section&nbsp;407 of the Sarbanes-Oxley
Act. The Board has determined that Mr.&nbsp;McArthur meets the standards of &#147;independence&#148;

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><a name="SandraO_MooseHasBeenADirectorOfAe_161847"></a><font style="font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Sandra O. Moose</font></i></b></font>
has been a Director of AES since April&nbsp;2004. Dr.&nbsp;Moose is President
of Strategic Advisory Services and previously was a Senior Vice President of
The Boston Consulting Group (&#147;BCG&#148;). She joined BCG in 1968, was a Director
since 1975, and a Senior Vice President through 2003. She managed BCG&#146;s New
York Office from 1988-1998 and was appointed Chair of the East Coast.
Dr.&nbsp;Moose received her PhD and MA in economics from Harvard University and
BA <i><font style="font-style:italic;">summa cum laude</font></i> in economics from
Wheaton College. Dr.&nbsp;Moose serves on the Boards of Directors of Verizon
Communications, Rohm and Haas Company, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation and IXIS
Advisor Funds and Loomis Sayles Funds where she is Chairperson of the Board of
Trustees. Dr.&nbsp;Moose serves on the Nominating and Corporate Governance
Committee and the Special Committee of the Board (and will serve on the newly
formed Finance and Investment Committee). The Board has determined that
Dr.&nbsp;Moose meets the standards of &#147;independence&#148; established by the NYSE
and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><a name="PhilipA_OdeenHasBeenADirectorOfAe_161851"></a><font style="font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Philip A. Odeen</font></i></b></font>
has been a Director of AES since May&nbsp;1, 2003. From July&nbsp;2004 to
present, Mr.&nbsp;Odeen has served as Non-Executive Chairman for Reynolds and
Reynolds Company. Mr.&nbsp;Odeen retired as Chairman of TRW&nbsp;Inc. in
December&nbsp;2002. Prior to joining TRW in 1997, Mr.&nbsp;Odeen was President
and Chief Executive Officer of BDM, which TRW acquired in 1997. From 1978 to
1992, Mr.&nbsp;Odeen was a Senior Consulting Partner with Coopers&nbsp;&amp;
Lybrand and served as Vice Chairman, management consulting services, from 1991
to 1992. From 1972 to 1978, he was Vice President of the Wilson Sporting Goods
Company. Mr.&nbsp;Odeen has served in senior positions with the Office of the
Secretary of Defense and the National Security Council staff. Mr.&nbsp;Odeen
graduated Phi Beta Kappa with a BA in government from the University of South
Dakota. He was a Fulbright Scholar to the United Kingdom and earned a master&#146;s
degree from the University of Wisconsin. He is a member of the Boards of
Directors of Avaya, Convergys Corporation, Northrop Grumman Corporation, and
Reynolds and Reynolds Company. Mr.&nbsp;Odeen chairs the Compensation Committee
and also serves on the Special Committee of the Board (and will serve on the
newly formed Finance and Investment Committee). The Board has determined that
Mr.&nbsp;Odeen meets the standards of &#147;independence&#148; established by the NYSE
and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><a name="CharlesO_RossottiHasBeenADirector_161922"></a><font style="font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Charles O.
Rossotti</font></i></b></font> has been a Director of AES since
March&nbsp;2003. Mr.&nbsp;Rossotti is a Senior Advisor with the Carlyle Group,
one of the world&#146;s largest private equity firms. From November&nbsp;1997 until
November&nbsp;2002, Mr.&nbsp;Rossotti was the Commissioner of Internal Revenue
at the United States Internal Revenue Service (&#147;IRS&#148;). Prior to joining the
IRS, Mr.&nbsp;Rossotti was a founder of American Management Systems,&nbsp;Inc.,
where he held the position of President from 1970-1989, Chief Executive
Officer from 1981 to 1993 and Chairman from 1989 to 1997. From 1965 to 1969, he
held various positions in the Office of Systems Analysis within the Office of
the Secretary of Defense. Mr.&nbsp;Rossotti graduated <i><font style="font-style:italic;">magna cum laude</font></i> from Georgetown University
and received an MBA with high distinction from Harvard Business School.
Mr.&nbsp;Rossotti serves on the Boards of Directors of Adesso Systems
Corporation, Liquid Engines,&nbsp;Inc., Compusearch Systems,&nbsp;Inc., and
Merrill Lynch&nbsp;&amp; Co.,&nbsp;Inc. Mr.&nbsp;Rossotti serves on the
Financial Audit Committee and the Compensation Committee of the Board.
Mr.&nbsp;Rossotti has been designated an Audit Committee Financial Expert
pursuant to Section&nbsp;407 of the </p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">8</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='8',FILE='C:\fc\94145337247_D11854_997353\7856-1-ca.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 14:54 2006' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Sarbanes-Oxley Act. The Board has determined that
Mr.&nbsp;Rossotti meets the standards of &#147;independence&#148; established by the NYSE
and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 10.0pt;"><a name="SvenSandstromHasBeenADirectorOfAe_161926"></a><font style="font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Sven Sandstrom</font></i></b></font>
has been a Director of AES since October&nbsp;2002. He is the former Managing
Director of the World Bank, retiring from the Bank in December&nbsp;2001.
Mr.&nbsp;Sandstrom currently serves as Director, Secretariat of the
International Task Force on Global Public Goods sponsored by, inter alia,
France, Sweden, Germany, and the United Kingdom. He is a member of the
Governing Council and Treasurer of the International Union for the Conservation
of Nature (IUCN). He co-chairs the funding negotiations for the Global Fund to
Fight AIDS, TB and Malaria. He chairs the funding negotiations for the African
Development Bank. Mr.&nbsp;Sandstrom serves on the Financial Audit Committee
and the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee of the Board.
Mr.&nbsp;Sandstrom has been designated an Audit Committee Financial Expert pursuant
to Section&nbsp;407 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. The Board has determined
that Mr.&nbsp;Sandstrom meets the standards of &#147;independence&#148; established by
the NYSE and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.</p>

<table border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border:none;border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;width:100.0%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="100%" valign="top" style="border:solid black 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:2.0pt 0pt 1.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font style="font-weight:bold;">THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS RECOMMENDS A VOTE <u>FOR</u> THE<br>
  ELECTION OF THE 10 DIRECTORS DISCUSSED ABOVE AND AS SET FORTH ON<br>
  THE PROXY BALLOT</font></b></p>
  </td>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;width:100.0%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="100%" valign="top" style="background:#EBEBEB;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:2.0pt 0pt;text-align:center;"><a name="TheCommitteesOfTheBoard_133402"></a><font size="3" style="font-size:12.0pt;">THE COMMITTEES OF THE BOARD</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">In 2005, the
Board maintained four standing committees and a Special Committee. The four
standing committees are the Financial Audit Committee, the Environment, Safety
and Technology Committee, the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee,
and the Compensation Committee. Each of the members of the Financial Audit
Committee, the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee, and the
Compensation Committee meet the standards of &#147;independence&#148; established by the
NYSE and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. In February&nbsp;2006, the Board
determined that the Special Committee would not be maintained for the upcoming
2006-2007 Board year and established a new committee, the Finance and
Investment Committee. A description of each Board committee is set forth in the
paragraphs located immediately below.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="FinancialAuditCommitteetheauditCo_042546"></a><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Financial Audit Committee (the &#147;Audit
Committee&#148;)</font></u></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Board has a
separately designated standing Audit Committee established in accordance with
Rule&nbsp;10A-3 of the Exchange Act of 1934 (the &#147;Exchange Act&#148;) and New
York Stock Exchange Rule&nbsp;303A.06. The members of the Audit Committee are
John A. Koskinen, John H. McArthur, Charles O. Rossotti and Sven Sandstrom. The
Audit Committee of the Board is responsible for the review and oversight of the
Company&#146;s performance with respect to its financial responsibilities and the
integrity of the Company&#146;s accounting and reporting practices. The Audit
Committee, on behalf of the Board, also appoints the Company&#146;s independent
auditors subject to Stockholder ratification at the Annual Meeting. The Audit
Committee operates under the Charter of the Financial Audit Committee adopted
and approved by the Board. A copy of the charter appears on the Company&#146;s web
site (<i><font style="font-style:italic;">www.aes.com</font></i>) and is also attached to
this Proxy Statement as Exhibit&nbsp;1. The members of the Audit Committee meet
the standards of &#147;independence&#148; established by the NYSE and the Sarbanes-Oxley
Act. Messrs.&nbsp;Koskinen, McArthur, Rossotti and Sandstrom have been
designated as Audit Committee Financial Experts under Section&nbsp;407 of the
Sarbanes-Oxley Act and determined to be &#147;financially literate&#148; as
required by the NYSE. The Audit Committee met twelve (12) times in 2005.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">9</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='9',FILE='C:\fc\94145337247_D11854_997353\7856-1-ca.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 14:54 2006' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

<div>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="CompensationCommittee_042553"></a><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Environment, Safety and Technology Committee
(the &#147;EST Committee&#148;)</font></u></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The EST
Committee monitors the environmental and safety compliance of the Company and
its subsidiaries; reviews and approves the scope of the Company&#146;s internal
environmental and safety compliance audit programs to consider the adequacy and
appropriateness of the programs being planned and performed; periodically
reviews the Company&#146;s commitment to, and implementation of, its principle to
act in a socially responsible way; and reviews and considers technology
developments applicable to the industry and the Company&#146;s businesses. The
members of the EST Committee are Kristina M. Johnson, John A. Koskinen, Philip
Lader and Roger W. Sant. The EST Committee operates under the Charter of the
Environment, Safety and Technology Committee adopted and approved by the Board.
A copy of the charter appears on the Company&#146;s web site (www.aes.com). The EST
Committee met five (5)&nbsp;times in 2005.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="NominatingAndCorporateGovernanceC_042548"></a><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee</font></u></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Nominating
and Corporate Governance Committee of the Board provides recommendations for
potential nominees for election to the Board, establishes compensation for
Directors, and also considers governance and social responsibility issues
relating to the Board and the Company. The members of the Nominating and
Corporate Governance Committee are Philip Lader, Sandra O. Moose and Sven
Sandstrom. Nominees for Director are selected on the basis of, among other
things, experience, knowledge, skills, expertise, integrity, ability to make
independent analytical inquiries, understanding of the Company&#146;s global
business environment and willingness to devote adequate time and effort to
Board responsibilities so as to enhance the Board&#146;s ability to oversee and
direct the affairs and business of the Company. In certain instances, the
Company engages a third party to assist in identifying potential nominees. The
Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee also considers potential
nominations for Director provided by Stockholders and submits any such
suggested nominations, when appropriate, to the Board for approval. Stockholder
nominees are evaluated using the criteria described above. Stockholders wishing
to recommend persons for consideration by the Committee as nominees for
election to the Company&#146;s Board can do so by writing to the Secretary of the
Company at 4300 Wilson Boulevard, Arlington, Virginia 22203. Any such
Stockholder nomination recommendation should provide the nominee&#146;s name,
biographical data and qualifications. Any such recommendation also must be
accompanied by a written statement from the person recommended for nomination
of his or her consent to be named as a nominee and, if nominated and elected,
to serve as a Director. The Company&#146;s By-Laws also contain a procedure for
Stockholder nomination of Directors. (See &#147;Stockholder Proposals and/or
Nominations for Director&#148; set forth in the Governance Matters section below.)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Nominating
and Corporate Governance Committee operates under the Charter of the Nominating
and Corporate Governance Committee adopted and approved by the Board. A copy of
the charter appears on the Company&#146;s web site (www.aes.com). The members of the
Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee meet the standards of
&#147;independence&#148; established by the NYSE and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. The
Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee met five (5)&nbsp;times in 2005.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="CompensationCommittee_122247"></a><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Compensation Committee</font></u></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The
Compensation Committee establishes rates of salary, bonuses, profit sharing
contributions, grants of stock options, restricted stock units, performance units,
retirement and other compensation for officers of AES and for such other
employees as the Board may designate. The members of the Compensation Committee
are Kristina M. Johnson, Philip A. Odeen and Charles O. Rossotti. The
Compensation Committee&#146;s principal objective in establishing compensation
policies is to develop and administer a comprehensive program designed to
attract and retain outstanding people. The Compensation Committee specifically
acts to evaluate the </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">10</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='10',FILE='C:\fc\941545765_D11854_997435\7856-1-cc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 15:05 2006' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">performance and
set the total compensation for executive officers of the Company, including the
CEO, in accordance with the guidelines discussed in the Compensation Committee
report set forth in this Proxy Statement. The Compensation Committee has
delegated to the CEO, subject to review by the Compensation Committee and the
Board, the power to set compensation for non-executive officers. All of the
members of the Compensation Committee are &#147;disinterested persons&#148; under the
provisions of Rule&nbsp;16b-3 adopted under the Securities Exchange Act
of 1934. The Compensation Committee operates under the charter of the
Compensation Committee adopted and approved by the Board. A copy of the charter
appears on the Company&#146;s web site (www.aes.com). The members of the
Compensation Committee meet the standards of &#147;independence&#148; established by the
NYSE and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. The Compensation Committee met six (6)&nbsp;times
in 2005.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="SpecialCommitteeAndFinanceAndInve_042555"></a><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Special Committee and Finance and Investment
Committee</font></u></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">On September&nbsp;4,
2002, the Special Committee of the Board was formed to facilitate
communications between the Board and management of the Company in connection
with the turnaround efforts faced at that time by the Company. During the 2005-2006
Board year, Richard Darman, John&nbsp;H. McArthur, Sandra&nbsp;O. Moose,
Philip&nbsp;A. Odeen and Roger&nbsp;W. Sant served as members of the Special
Committee. The Special Committee was available to provide advice and assistance
to Company management on a more frequent basis than the regularly scheduled
meetings of the Board. The Special Committee met six (6)&nbsp;times in 2005. At
the February&nbsp;24, 2006 Board meeting, in part due to the Company&#146;s
successful turnaround efforts, the Board determined to discontinue the Special
Committee. The Board, at its February&nbsp;24, 2006 meeting, also determined to
establish a new Committee called the Finance and Investment Committee. The
Finance and Investment Committee will focus on the evaluation of strategic
plans, potential investments, budgets, proposed equity and/or debt offerings and
also be available to provide advice and assistance to Company management on a
more frequent basis than the regularly scheduled meetings of the Board. The
members of the Finance and Investment Committee will be Richard Darman
(chairman), John H. McArthur, Sandra O. Moose and Phillip A. Odeen.</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;width:100.0%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="100%" valign="top" style="background:#EBEBEB;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:2.0pt 0pt;text-align:center;"><a name="C_144243"></a><font size="3" style="font-size:12.0pt;">COMPENSATION OF DIRECTORS</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">In 2004, the
Board revised the compensation structure for outside Directors. The revised
structure was intended to meet the following goals: promote the recruitment of
talented and experienced Directors to the Board; compensate outside Directors
for the increased workload and risk inherent in the Director position; simplify
the compensation structure by removing individual Board and committee meeting
fees and thereby improve the clarity of the compensation structure for
Stockholders and other stakeholders of the Company; and decrease the emphasis
on option grants as compensation, while retaining a strong financial incentive
for Directors to maintain and promote the long-term health and viability of the
Company. This revised compensation structure was the basis for determining
Board compensation for Board year 2005-2006. Directors who are also
officers of AES are not paid any fees or additional compensation for service as
a member of AES&#146;s Board or any committee thereof. Paul Hanrahan, the President
and Chief Executive Officer of AES, is the only officer of the Company who
serves on the Board.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">A description
of the individual components of the compensation structure for outside
Directors is set forth in the paragraphs immediately below.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="AnnualRetainer_042629"></a><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Annual Retainer</font></u></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Under the Board&#146;s
compensation structure, each outside Director receives a $50,000 annual
retainer with a requirement that 34% of such retainer be deferred in the form
of stock units pursuant to the existing AES </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">11</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='11',FILE='C:\fc\941545765_D11854_997435\7856-1-cc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 15:05 2006' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Corporation
Deferred Compensation Plan for Directors (&#147;Director Plan&#148;). Directors may
elect, but are not required, to defer more than the 34% mandatory deferral. Any
amount of the annual retainer that is elected to be deferred by a Director
above the mandatory deferral will be credited to such Director in stock units
equivalent to 1.3 times the elected deferred amount.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="CommitteeAndCommitteeChairRetaine_042632"></a><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Committee and Committee Chair Retainer</font></u></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Directors
receive a $10,000 committee retainer for each Board committee on which they
serve. If a Director serves as Chair of a committee, the Director receives the
applicable Committee Chair fee (as noted below in this paragraph), but does not
receive the committee retainer. Directors do not receive committee meeting
attendance fees as Board members are expected to attend and participate fully
in all meetings of committees on which they serve. Directors may elect to defer
a portion or the entire committee retainer in the form of stock units pursuant
to the Director Plan. A Director serving as a Committee Chair is compensated as
follows: the Audit Committee Chair and the Special Committee Chair receive
$25,000 per year; the remaining Committee Chairs receive $15,000 per year.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="DeferredIncentiveCompensationGran_042633"></a><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Deferred Incentive Compensation Grant</font></u></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Directors
receive an annual Deferred Incentive Compensation Grant valued at $80,000.
Directors may elect to take the Deferred Incentive Compensation Grant in the
form of stock units (vested immediately), an option grant or a mix of stock
units and options. To the extent a Director elects to receive options, such
options shall be subject to a ten-year term and a three-year vesting schedule;
to be vested in three equal installments upon the anniversary of the date of
grant. The Black Scholes valuation methodology is employed to determine the
number of shares of stock which is awarded and grants are equal to 100% of the
quoted market price on the date of grant. Unless otherwise determined, options
shall expire 180 days after termination of service. Units awarded pursuant to
the Deferred Incentive Compensation grant will be paid out in accordance with
409(A)&nbsp;of the Internal Revenue Code and the terms of the relevant plan
documents.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><a name="TheChairmanOfTheBoard_042634"></a><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Chairman of the Board</font></u></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Chairman of
the Board is required to be a non-executive of AES. In addition to the duties
of the Chairman related to the planning and structure of Board meetings and
oversight of Board responsibilities, the Chairman, although not an officer or
employee of the Company, serves as a member of the Company&#146;s Executive Office
and attends the meetings of the Executive Office. The Chairman also is required
to serve as an ex-officio member of all Board committees and therefore is
expected to attend all committee meetings. The Chairman receives compensation
in an amount equal to 2.5 times the annual retainer and the Deferred Incentive
Compensation grant. As with other Board members, the Chairman is required to
defer 34% of the annual retainer in the form of stock units, but is permitted
to elect to defer more than the mandatory 34% deferral. Any amount of the
annual retainer above the mandatory deferral amount that is deferred by the
Chairman will be valued at 1.3 times the elected deferred amount. The Chairman
receives in total $25,000 for the required service as an ex-officio member of
the committees of the Board. If a Chairman of the Board serves as the Chairman
of a committee, the Chairman receives the Chairman fee applicable to such
committee.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">12</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='12',FILE='C:\fc\941545765_D11854_997435\7856-1-cc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 15:05 2006' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><a name="Proposal2RatificationOfTheAppoint_144252"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;width:100.0%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="100%" valign="top" style="background:#EBEBEB;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:3.0pt 0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><font size="3" style="font-size:12.0pt;">PROPOSAL 2: RATIFICATION OF THE
  APPOINTMENT OF AUDITORS</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Board has
appointed Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP, a firm of independent public
accountants, as auditors to examine and report to Stockholders on the
consolidated financial statements for the Company and its subsidiaries for the
calendar year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP has
acted as the Company&#146;s independent auditors since 1981. The appointment was
made upon the recommendation of the Audit Committee of the Board. The
appointment of Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP is subject to ratification by the
Company&#146;s Stockholders at the Annual Meeting. Representatives of Deloitte&nbsp;&amp;
Touche LLP will be present at the Annual Meeting and will be given an
opportunity to make a statement. Such representatives also will be available to
respond to appropriate questions.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Board
recommends that the Stockholders ratify the appointment of Deloitte&nbsp;&amp;
Touche LLP. The Board intends to introduce at the forthcoming 2006 Annual
Meeting of Stockholders the following resolution (designated herein as Proposal
2):</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 36.0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#147;RESOLVED, that
the appointment by the Board of Directors of Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP as
independent auditors of this Company for the year 2006 is hereby approved,
ratified and confirmed.&#148;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Ratification
will be confirmed if a majority of the votes of the shares of Common Stock of
the Company present in person or represented by Proxy and entitled to vote at
the Annual Meeting, at which a quorum is present, are received and voted in
favor of the ratification of Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP as independent
auditors of this Company for the year 2006.</font></p>

<table border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border:none;border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;width:100.0%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="100%" valign="top" style="border:solid black 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:4.0pt 0pt 3.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font style="font-weight:bold;">THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS RECOMMENDS A VOTE <u>FOR</u> THE RATIFICATION
  OF<br>
  THE APPOINTMENT OF DELOITTE&nbsp;&amp; TOUCHE LLP AS INDEPENDENT AUDITORS<br>
  OF THE COMPANY.</font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">13</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='13',FILE='C:\fc\941545765_D11854_997435\7856-1-cc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 15:05 2006' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><a name="R_144341"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<div align="center">

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;">
 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF">
  <td width="609" valign="top" style="background:#EBEBEB;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:456.4pt;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:3.0pt 0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">REPORT OF THE FINANCIAL AUDIT COMMITTEE</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Audit
Committee held twelve (12) scheduled meetings during fiscal 2005. The meetings
of the Audit Committee were designed to address the Committee&#146;s responsibility
for the review and oversight of the Company&#146;s performance with respect to the
Company&#146;s financial responsibilities and the integrity of the Company&#146;s
accounting and reporting practices. In addition to discussions with the CEO,
CFO and other members of Company management regarding the preparation of the
Company&#146;s financial statements and operating results, including the financial
statements filed in connection with the 2005 restatement efforts, the Audit
Committee received periodic reports from the Company&#146;s Internal Audit,
Compliance and Legal departments. Such reports addressed, among other matters,
ongoing projects, control assessments and audits being conducted by the
Internal Audit department, reports to the Company&#146;s compliance hotline and/or
issues involving the Company&#146;s Code of Business Conduct and Ethics, material
litigation and significant legal developments involving the Company and/or its
subsidiaries, and proposed organizational changes. During 2005, the Committee
also received periodic reports regarding the Company&#146;s efforts to comply with
section&nbsp;404 of Sarbanes-Oxley and efforts related to the completion
and filings of the Company&#146;s restated financial statements. In addition to the
scheduled meetings of the Committee, the members of the Audit Committee, as a
Committee or individually, held periodic telephonic discussions and/or
in-person meetings with the CEO, CFO and various members of the Internal Audit,
Compliance, and Legal departments regarding various subjects. Such informal
periodic meetings and discussions permit the Audit Committee to provide advice
and assistance to Company management on a more frequent basis than the
regularly scheduled meetings of the Committee.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The meetings of
the Audit Committee also were designed to facilitate and encourage
communication among the Audit Committee, the Company, and the Company&#146;s
independent auditors, Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP. The Audit Committee
discussed with the Company&#146;s independent auditors the overall scope and plans
for their respective audits, and met with the independent auditors, with and
without management present, to discuss the results of their examinations and
their evaluations of the Company&#146;s internal controls. The Audit Committee also
discussed with the independent auditors the efforts expended by the Company in
connection with the preparation and filing of the restated financial
statements.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Company,
neither the Audit Committee nor the independent auditor, is responsible for the
preparation of the Company&#146;s financial statements and its operating results and
for the appropriate safekeeping of the Company&#146;s assets. The independent
auditor&#146;s responsibility is to attest to the fair presentation of the financial
statements. The independent auditor is accountable to the Audit Committee, and
the Audit Committee has the ultimate authority and responsibility to select,
evaluate and, where appropriate, replace the independent auditor. The role of
the Audit Committee is to be satisfied that both the Company and the
independent auditor discharge their respective responsibilities effectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Audit
Committee has reviewed and discussed the audited consolidated financial
statements for the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 with management and
Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Audit
Committee also discussed with the independent auditors matters required to be
discussed with audit committees under generally accepted auditing standards,
including, among other things, matters related to the conduct of the audit of
the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements and the matters required to be
discussed by Statement on Auditing Standards No.&nbsp;61, Communication with
Audit Committees, as amended by Statement on Auditing Standards No.&nbsp;90,
Audit Committee Communications.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">14</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='14',FILE='C:\fc\941545765_D11854_997435\7856-1-cc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 15:05 2006' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Company&#146;s
independent auditors provided to the Audit Committee the written disclosures
and the letter required by Independence Standards Board Standard No.&nbsp;1,
Independence Discussions with Audit Committees. The independent auditors also
discussed with the Audit Committee their independence from the Company. When
considering Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP&#146;s independence, the Audit Committee
considered whether their provision of services to the Company beyond those
rendered in connection with their audit and review of the Company&#146;s
consolidated financial statements was compatible with maintaining their
independence. The Audit Committee also reviewed and approved, among other
things, the amount of fees paid to Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP for audit and
non-audit services. (Please see the principal accounting firm fees chart
located in the section immediately below in this Proxy Statement titled &#147;Information
Regarding the Independent Public Auditor&#146;s Fees, Services and Independence&#148;.)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Based on its
review and the meetings, discussions and reports described above, and subject
to the limitations on its role and responsibilities referred to above and in
the Audit Committee Charter, the Audit Committee recommended to the Board that
the Company&#146;s audited consolidated financial statements for the fiscal year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 be included in the Company&#146;s Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. The Audit Committee also selected
Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP, subject to ratification by the Stockholders at
the Annual Meeting, as the Company&#146;s independent auditors for the fiscal year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Financial Audit Committee:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">John H.
McArthur, Chairman<br>
John A. Koskinen<br>
Charles O. Rossotti<br>
Sven Sandstrom</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">15</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='C:\fc\941545765_D11854_997435\7856-1-cc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  4 15:05 2006' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><a name="I_144349"></a><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="background:#EBEBEB;border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;width:100.0%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="100%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:4.0pt 0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><font size="3" style="font-size:12.0pt;">INFORMATION REGARDING THE INDEPENDENT<br>
  REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM FEES, SERVICES<br>
  AND INDEPENDENCE</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The following
table outlines the aggregate fees billed to the Company for the fiscal years
ending December&nbsp;31, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004 by the Company&#146;s
principal accounting firm, Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP, the member firms of
Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, and their respective affiliates which includes
Deloitte Consulting (collectively, &#147;Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche&#148;):</font></p>

<div align="center">

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;">
 <tr>
  <td width="341" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:256.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="65" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:49.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.5pt;">2005</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="65" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:49.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.5pt;">2004</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF">
  <td width="341" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:256.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Audit Fees:</font></p>

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">19,285,918</font></p>

  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
